p: Although decreased size at maturity at the range edge is consistent with range expansion predictions [ 15– 17], it is an unusual contrast to the Bergmann’s cline demonstrated by A. pisonii throughout its native range. This contrast is likely due to habitat-specific differences associated with A. pisonii’s range expansion into novel marsh habitat. Organisms at the range edge often face selective pressures that are unique compared to those experienced by individuals within the core of the species’ range [ 15– 17, 42]. Just as gradients in biotic and abiotic interactions underlie Bergmann’s clines, habitat-specific differences in these elements may also influence life history traits such as body size and size at maturity [ 17].
